<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
- The authors clearly state that they had a pre-specified protocol for their systematic review.
- [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion."
- The authors used two independent investigators for study selection and data extraction, with a third investigator resolving any conflicts.
- [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012."
- The authors searched multiple databases and provided the time frame for their search.
- [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- No specific mention of searching for grey or unpublished literature is made in the text.
- The authors do not specify whether they included grey literature in their search.
- [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- "Using the stated search strategy, 3081 papers were identified. After removal of duplicates, 751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria, all of which were cohort studies."
- The authors provide a number of studies identified, screened, and included, but do not provide a list of these studies.
- [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR."
- "The largest study was Owen 2010 [2] with 290 eligible patients. The majority of the remaining studies included fewer than 50 participants (Table 2)."
- The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, such as the number of participants and the interventions they underwent.
- [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
- The authors state that they assessed the quality of the included studies using recognized tools.
- [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- "Despite showing some benefit of OPFC over SR, our results are tempered by the low quality of the available studies, which were small and variably reported."
- The authors explicitly state that the quality of the included studies influenced their conclusions.
- [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement."
- The authors describe the methods they used to combine the findings of the studies.
- [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- No specific mention of assessing for publication bias is made in the text.
- The authors do not mention assessing for publication bias.
- [No]

The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript. Competing Interests: The authors have declared that no competing interests exist."
- The authors clearly state the source of funding for the systematic review and declare no competing interests.

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- "Challenges of Improving the Evidence Base in Smaller Surgical Specialties, as Highlighted by a Systematic Review of Gastroschisis Management"
- The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
- [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- The abstract provides a structured summary that includes the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
- [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- "With variation existing around the specifics of management of some of the most common neonatal surgical conditions including oesophageal atresia, gastroschisis and Hirschsprung’s disease, research should be commonplace."
- The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of existing knowledge.
- [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- "The aim of this study, therefore, was to perform a systematic review of the literature comparing outcomes of infants with simple gastroschisis following either OPFC or SR."
- The authors provide an explicit statement of the research question, including participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes.
- [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
- The authors indicate that a review protocol exists and provide its registration number.
- [Yes]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- "Studies were included if they involved infants born with simple gastroschisis, defined as gastroschisis with an intact continuous bowel that is not compromised or breached at delivery or presentation."
- "Correction of gastroschisis can broadly be broken down into two parts; method of visceral reduction, and method of closure. Our intervention of interest was SR, defined as use of a silo (preformed, custom or improvised) for staged reduction of the abdominal viscera, followed by any form of defect closure."
- The authors specify the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
- "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012."
- The authors describe the information sources and the dates of coverage for their search.
- [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- "Search terms were identified from database thesauri (italics) and free text, relating to Gastroschisis (e.g. Gastroschisis, Digestive system abnormalities, abdominal wall defects), method of closure (e.g. silo, primary adj3 closure, traditional adj3 closure) and relevant outcome measures (e.g. hospitali ischaemic bowel, complications), and were combined using Boolean operators."
- The authors present their search strategy, but do not provide enough detail for it to be fully replicated.
- [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
- "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK)."
- The authors state the process for selecting studies.
- [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
- "Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion. Where required, unpublished data were requested from the authors of each of the included studies to allow for meta-analysis."
- The authors describe the method of data extraction and the process for obtaining and confirming data.
- [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
- "Primary outcome measures: 1. Mortality 2. Length of hospital stay 3. Time to complete enteral feeding/duration of parenteral feeding"
- "Secondary outcome measures: 1. Duration of ventilator use 2. Infective complication 3. Perforation 4. Ischaemic bowel 5. Necrotising Enterocolitis (NEC) 6. Anastomotic stricture 7. Adhesional small bowel obstruction 8. Complications related to stoma 9. Short bowel syndrome 10. Liver disease associated with intestinal failure"
- The authors list and define all variables for which data were sought.
- [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
- "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
- The authors describe the methods used for assessing the risk of bias in individual studies.
- [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
- "Dichotomous outcomes were meta-analysed using Mantel–Haenszel fixed effects methods to produce summary odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals."
- The authors state the principal summary measures used in their analysis.
- [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
- "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement."
- The authors describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
- [Yes]

P15. Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
- No specific mention of assessing for risk of bias across studies is made in the text.
- The authors do not specify any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
- [No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
- No specific mention of additional analyses is made in the text.
- The authors do not describe any additional analyses.
- [No]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
- "Using the stated search strategy, 3081 papers were identified. After removal of duplicates, 751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria, all of which were cohort studies."
- The authors provide numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.
- [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
- "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR."
- "The largest study was Owen 2010 [2] with 290 eligible patients. The majority of the remaining studies included fewer than 50 participants (Table 2)."
- The authors present characteristics for each study and provide citations.
- [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
- No specific mention of presenting data on risk of bias within each study is made in the text.
- The authors do not present data on risk of bias within each study.
- [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
- "All three primary outcome measures appeared to favour the OPFC group over the SR group. Both length of stay and number of post-operative days to complete enteral feeding were clinically and statistically significantly longer in the SR group, with a mean difference of 8.97 days, (95% CI 2.14–15.80 days), and a mean difference of 7.19 days (95%CI 2.01–12.36 days) respectively (Fig. 2)."
- The authors present simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates with confidence intervals.
- [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
- "Both length of stay and number of post-operative days to complete enteral feeding were clinically and statistically significantly longer in the SR group, with a mean difference of 8.97 days, (95% CI 2.14–15.80 days), and a mean difference of 7.19 days (95%CI 2.01–12.36 days) respectively (Fig. 2)."
- The authors present the results of their meta-analysis, including confidence intervals.
- [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
- No specific mention of presenting results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies is made in the text.
- The authors do not present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
- [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
- No specific mention of additional analyses is made in the text.
- The authors do not give results of any additional analyses.
- [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
- "Our results would appear to suggest a potential benefit to OPFC over SR. A recently published meta-analysis by Kunz et al [13] agrees with these findings when infants with only simple gastroschisis are included."
- The authors summarize the main findings and discuss the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
- [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
- "This study has highlighted three key themes that recur throughout research into paediatric surgery, and which help account for the lack of a robust evidence base for clinical practice. These are; limitations of study type, limitations of methodology, and inconsistency in outcomes and definitions."
- The authors discuss limitations at the study and review level.
- [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- "Our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
- "We therefore believe that the way to promote evidence-based paediatric surgery is by enhancing collaboration between centres."
- The authors provide a general interpretation of the results and discuss implications for future research.
- [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
- "Funding: Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorhip. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http://www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
- The authors describe the sources of funding for the systematic review and the role of the funders.
- [Yes]

<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "The PRISMA statement, checklist and flowchart were referenced to achieve the highest standard in reporting items for a systematic review and meta-analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the use of the PRISMA statement, which suggests a pre-planned methodology.
- Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "Data extraction was conducted by 2 reviewers (LB & AB) using a predefined data extraction worksheet."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that two reviewers independently conducted data extraction.
- Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "A systematic search of electronic databases was performed to identify all relevant studies comparing two or more gastrostomy insertion techniques in children reporting procedural-related complication rates."
- Reasoning: The authors describe a comprehensive search strategy across multiple databases.
- Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: "Only published data were included in our study."
- Reasoning: The authors explicitly state that only published data were included, suggesting that grey literature was not considered.
- Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "The search strategy for the review resulted in 22 studies meeting inclusion criteria, with 5346 participants overall."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the number of studies included but do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
- Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "Of the 22 studies identified, the median MINORS score of all studies was 14 (range 10–16), max = 24."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, such as the MINORS score.
- Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: "The methodological index for non-randomized studies (MINORS) was utilized to determine the quality of studies and risk of bias."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the use of the MINORS index to assess the quality of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "This review suggests that a laparoscopic approach is affiliated with decreased patient morbidity requiring reoperation when compared to an endoscopic gastrostomy insertion approach."
- Reasoning: The authors' conclusions are based on the results of the included studies, which were assessed for quality.
- Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "Meta-analysis was preformed for primary and secondary outcomes using RevMan 5.1 (Copenhagen)."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the use of meta-analysis to combine the findings of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: "Publication bias was evaluated through the generation of a funnel plot of standard error against the log odds ratio."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the use of a funnel plot to assess publication bias.
- Response: [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: Not available.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention any conflicts of interest in the provided text.
- Response: [No]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Quote: "Laparoscopic vs open varicocelectomy in children and adolescents: review of the recent literature and meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Answer: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: Laparoscopic varicocelectomy has gained popularity in recent years. The aim of this study was to identify clinical evidence about the reliability of this technique in the recent literature. Methods: We performed a Medline search for articles published during the last 10 years, using the key words “varicocele,” “treatment,” and “adolescent.” As limits, we used last 10 years, adolescent, clinical trials, randomized controlled trials, meta-analysis, and multicenter retrospective and prospective studies. The results were investigated in recurrence and hydrocele formation. Results: We pooled 37 studies, but 26 of these were excluded because they were neither relevant nor concerned an adolescent population. Meta-analysis showed that there was no statistical difference between laparoscopic surgery and open surgery in recurrence rate and postoperative hydrocele rate. In the laparoscopic group, the incidence of recurrence was higher in the patients undergoing artery ligation compared to patients undergoing artery and venous ligation. Furthermore, a lower rate of postoperative hydrocele was recorded in patients undergoing dye injections before laparoscopic ligation. Conclusions: Meta-analysis and literature analysis showed that the results after laparoscopic varicocelectomy are comparable to other surgical procedures. The laparoscopic approach has the advantage to treat simultaneously bilateral varicocele."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the review, including the background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
- Answer: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Quote: "Varicocele is generally considered the most common correctable cause of male infertility [1,2]. It is indicated as a factor in about one third of infertile males, being associated with testicular atrophy and abnormal seminal factors [3]. Varicocele occurs in 10% to 15% of children and adolescents [4,5]. Several treatment options have been used, including spermatic vein sclerotherapy or embolization, open inguinal ligation of the spermatic vein, subinguinal microscopic varicocelectomy, and, most recently, laparoscopy, but the ideal method for varicocele treatment is still controversial [6-8]."

<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: "Our objective was to compare the outcomes of these procedures in a systematic review and meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The authors stated their research question and objectives before conducting the review.
Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention any process of duplicate study selection or data extraction.
Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We sought all publications describing both techniques through MEDLINE, Embase, and CENTRAL."
Reasoning: The authors mentioned the databases they used for their literature search.
Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention whether they included grey literature in their search.
Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: "Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis are detailed in Table 1."
Reasoning: The authors provided a table detailing the characteristics of the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "Two researchers independently assessed each study for methodological quality using MINORS."
Reasoning: The authors used the MINORS tool to assess the quality of the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "Our results should be interpreted with caution owing to the nature of the included studies."
Reasoning: The authors considered the quality of the included studies when formulating their conclusions.
Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "We conducted our meta-analyses using Review Manager 5.2."
Reasoning: The authors used a recognized tool for conducting their meta-analysis.
Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: "To address the risk of publication bias, we created a funnel plot for the recurrence outcome."
Reasoning: The authors assessed the likelihood of publication bias using a funnel plot.
Response: [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention any potential conflicts of interest.
Response: [No]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "Minimally invasive versus open repair of Bochdalek hernia: a meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
Quotes: The abstract section.
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the study.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Quotes: "Surgery for CDH repair can be performed by the traditional open approach (either laparotomy or thoracotomy), or by minimally invasive surgery (MIS), which has become increasingly popular since the late 1990s [3]."
Reasoning: The authors provided a rationale for their review.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
Quotes: "Thus, our objective was to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis of all published literature comparing surgical repair techniques for CDH."
Reasoning: The authors stated their objectives and the questions they were addressing.
Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention a review protocol or registration.
Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
Quotes: "We excluded any studies that did not pertain to humans and children. We also excluded editorials, case reviews, and any studies that did not compare outcomes of MIS with open surgery for Bochdalek-type hernias."
Reasoning: The authors specified their eligibility criteria.
Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
Quotes: "To identify all studies comparing MIS with open surgery for CDH repair, we conducted an electronic search of MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)."
Reasoning: The authors described their information sources.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
Quotes: "We used the keywords “diaphragmatic hernia”, “thoracoscopy”, “laparoscopy”, “minimally invasive surgery”, and “open”."
Reasoning: The authors presented their search strategy.
Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
Quotes: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: The authors described their study selection process.
Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not describe their data collection process.
Response: [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
Quotes: "Our primary outcome of interest was hernia recurrence after surgery. Secondary outcomes included operative time, total length of stay (LOS), postoperative ventilator time and postoperative mortality."
Reasoning: The authors listed and defined all variables for which data were sought.
Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Quotes: "Two researchers independently assessed each study for methodological quality using MINORS."
Reasoning: The authors described their methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
Quotes: "We used weighted mean differences to analyze continuous data and odds ratios to analyze categorical variables."
Reasoning: The authors stated their principal summary measures.
Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
Quotes: "For each outcome, we first assessed the heterogeneity of the studies (Chi 2 test and I 2 statistic). When heterogeneity was low to moderate (Q test p N 0.10, I 2 b 50%), we used a fixed-effects model. When heterogeneity was moderate to high (Q test p b 0.10, I 2 N 50%), we used a random-effects model [7]."
Reasoning: The authors described their methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
Response: [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
Quotes: "To address the risk of publication bias, we created a funnel plot for the recurrence outcome."
Reasoning: The authors assessed the risk of bias across studies.
Response: [Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
Quotes: "When we conducted a subgroup analysis to examine recurrences within different types of repair (primary and patch repair), we found that the recurrence rate was higher after MIS with patch repair only; for primary repair there was no difference between MIS and open surgery."
Reasoning: The authors described their methods of additional analyses.
Response: [Yes]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
Quotes: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: The authors provided numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.
Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
Quotes: "Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis are detailed in Table 1."
Reasoning: The authors presented characteristics for each study.
Response: [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
Quotes: "The MINORS scores for our included studies ranged from 13 to 16, with a median score of 14."
Reasoning: The authors presented data on risk of bias of each study.
Response: [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
Quotes: "In our pooled analysis, we found that recurrence was significantly more likely after MIS than open surgery (OR 2.81 [1.75, 4.56] p b 0.001, Fig. 3A)."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of individual studies.
Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
Quotes: "In our pooled analysis, we found that recurrence was significantly more likely after MIS than open surgery (OR 2.81 [1.75, 4.56] p b 0.001, Fig. 3A)."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of their meta-analysis.
Response: [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
Quotes: "To address the risk of publication bias, we created a funnel plot for the recurrence outcome."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of their assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Response: [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
Quotes: "When we conducted a subgroup analysis to examine recurrences within different types of repair (primary and patch repair), we found that the recurrence rate was higher after MIS with patch repair only; for primary repair there was no difference between MIS and open surgery."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of their additional analyses.
Response: [Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
Quotes: "Our results indicate that recurrence of Bochdalek hernia is higher following MIS than open surgery when patch repair is performed."
Reasoning: The authors summarized their main findings.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
Quotes: "Our results should be interpreted with caution owing to the nature of the included studies."
Reasoning: The authors discussed the limitations of their study.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
Quotes: "As such, surgeons should exercise great caution when attempting MIS for CDH repair; ideally, this procedure should be performed by experienced surgeons with a high level of comfort with MIS in this age group."
Reasoning: The authors provided a general interpretation of their results and implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention any sources of funding for their systematic review.
Response: [No]

Quotes: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: The authors provided numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.
Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
Quotes: "Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis are detailed in Table 1."
Reasoning: The authors presented characteristics for each study.
Response: [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
Quotes: "The MINORS scores for our included studies ranged from 13 to 16, with a median score of 14."
Reasoning: The authors presented data on risk of bias of each study.
Response: [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
Quotes: "In our pooled analysis, we found that recurrence was significantly more likely after MIS than open surgery (OR 2.81 [1.75, 4.56] p b 0.001, Fig. 3A)."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of individual studies.
Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
Quotes: "In our pooled analysis, we found that recurrence was significantly more likely after MIS than open surgery (OR 2.81 [1.75, 4.56] p b 0.001, Fig. 3A)."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of their meta-analysis.
Response: [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
Quotes: "To address the risk of publication bias, we created a funnel plot for the recurrence outcome."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of their assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Response: [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
Quotes: "When we conducted a subgroup analysis to examine recurrences within different types of repair (primary and patch repair), we found that the recurrence rate was higher after MIS with patch repair only; for primary repair there was no difference between MIS and open surgery."
Reasoning: The authors presented results of their additional analyses.
Response: [Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
Quotes: "Our results indicate that recurrence of Bochdalek hernia is higher following MIS than open surgery when patch repair is performed."
Reasoning: The authors summarized their main findings.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
Quotes: "Our results should be interpreted with caution owing to the nature of the included studies."
Reasoning: The authors discussed the limitations of their study.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
Quotes: "As such, surgeons should exercise great caution when attempting MIS for CDH repair; ideally, this procedure should be performed by experienced surgeons with a high level of comfort with MIS in this age group."
Reasoning: The authors provided a general interpretation of their results and implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
Quotes: None.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention any sources of funding for their systematic review.
Response: [No]

<AMSTAR>
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Quote: "In light of uncertainty and controversy, we undertook a systematic review of the available literature to determine (1) whether screening of IRA is obligatory in ‘‘asymptomatic’’ patients with heterotaxy and (2) whether detection of a rotational anomaly warrant(s) surgical correction in such a fragile patient cohort."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly state the research question and objectives of the review.
- Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Quote: "Two reviewers (P.S.C., S.S.) performed the study selection, data extraction, and quality assessment processes independently and all data was recorded in tabular form electronically. Disagreements were resolved by discussion or consultation with the third reviewer/senior corresponding author who conceived the study (P.D.L.)."
- Reasoning: The authors describe a process of independent study selection and data extraction by two reviewers.
- Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Quote: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search."
- Reasoning: The authors describe a comprehensive search strategy using multiple databases and additional sources.
- Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: "Conference proceedings and unpublished data were screened additionally."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that they included grey literature in their search.
- Response: [Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Quote: "Nineteen studies were included for systematic review."
- Reasoning: The authors mention the number of studies included but do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
- Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Quote: "Table 2 summarizes the main characteristics of the 19 included studies."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a table summarizing the characteristics of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Quote: "Quality of manuscripts was evaluated by using the Methodological Index for Nonrandomized Studies (MINORS) criteria."
- Reasoning: The authors describe the use of a quality assessment tool for the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Quote: "As all studies identified were retrospective analyses, the Methodological Index for Non-randomized Studies (MINORS) was employed to assess methodological quality."
- Reasoning: The authors mention that they considered the quality of the studies in their analysis.
- Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Quote: "All studies were retrospective case series (meta-analysis was therefore not formally undertaken other than cumulative totals and percentages of data included)."
- Reasoning: The authors did not perform a meta-analysis, but they did combine the findings of the studies in a descriptive manner.
- Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Quote: Not applicable.
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing for publication bias.
- Response: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Quote: "No funding was sought or received for this work."
- Reasoning: The authors disclose that they did not receive any funding for the review.
- Response: [Yes]

<PRISMA>
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

P2. [...] "Methods: A systematic review [according to PRISMA guidelines] was conducted using CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases" [...] "Results: Nineteen studies met the eligibility criteria but reporting was adequate for 9" [...] "Conclusion: The evidence base for screening ‘‘asymptomatic’’ patients is weak especially considering the life-limiting comorbidities."

- Response: [Yes]

- Quote: "Heterotaxy is an abnormal arrangement of thoraco-abdominal viscera across a left-to-right axis" [...] "Intestinal rotational abnormalities (IRAs) may be identified among 33% to 89% of patients with heterotaxy" [...] "The magnitude of this risk remains unknown."

- Quote: "In light of uncertainty and controversy, we undertook a systematic review of the available literature to determine (1) whether screening of IRA is obligatory in ‘‘asymptomatic’’ patients with heterotaxy and (2) whether detection of a rotational anomaly warrant(s) surgical correction in such a fragile patient cohort."

- Response: [Yes]

- Quote: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/A928)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a description of the search strategy used.

- Quote: "Two reviewers (P.S.C., S.S.) performed the study selection, data extraction, and quality assessment processes independently and all data was recorded in tabular form electronically. A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Quote: Not available.

- Quote: Not available.

- Reasoning: The authors specify their eligibility criteria.
